body:
Hi @John1231983 ,

Thanks for your message -- I wish you could have voted for the best paper award too, we were that close :)

Both subject-to-subject and subject-to-atlas are applicable in real settings -- it just depends which application you are interested in. 

While we show atlas-to-subject registration in the main MICCAI paper, training subject-to-subject networks is trivial (and we show results of this in the TMI paper for example for the non-diffeomorphic network) -- simply change the generator from `miccai2018_gen` to `miccai2018_gen_s2s`, and it will feed in two subject scans during training -- and the network will learn to do this. We recommend using the larger network designs for this (e.g. double the numbers in `nf_enc` and `nf_dec`).

You can also use voxelmorph to register between modalities (like `t1` to `t2`) -- simple change the cost function to mutual information.

In short, to answer your question, voxelmorph can definitely be used to do scan-to-scan, it does not have to be only for scan-to-atlas.

Got it. Just change the atlas to subject-fixed and the network can learn!

I agreed that we can use MI for the multi-modality image. How about between subjects with the same modality? In my dataset, I used MSE and it does not work well.
For same modality, I would recommend NCC -- although MSE has worked okay in our experiments. It would depend on how well your data is processed/normalized, though.

@adalca : Let I explain my issue in this thread. I will describe all concepts and you can check what I was wrong. 

I have the OAIS dataset that includes 20 real brain subjects with different rotation (https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn3281031) -may need to login to download.

![step0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63881880-c47c3180-c99e-11e9-9782-6719bd09fcd4.png)

- First step: I *linear rigid register* each subject to a template in MNI space (file name: OASIS-TRT-20_template_in_MNI152.nii.gz in https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn3241511)

![step1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63881892-cb0aa900-c99e-11e9-9c9b-10780575a74b.png)

- Second steps: In the 20 **aligned** images, I used 18 subjects for training and 2 subjects for validation. In my application that is registration subject-to-subject. So, for training, I randomly choose one subject in the 18 subjects is for the moving subjects, and randomly select 1 subjects from 17 remaining subjects is for fixed. Then the deformation field will be learned. All images are normalized to [0,1]
 
- Third step: for testing, we have two subjects. So, I choose 1 subject as fixed and 1 subjects for moving. I send it to the network to obtain the moved image. This is the result [from left to right: Moving-Fixed: next row: Moved by voxelmorph and deformation]

![step4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63883722-c7792100-c9a2-11e9-877d-7fa27007d889.png)

It looks that the moved image does not change so much in comparsion with moving image. The loss is NCC loss and smooth loss with lambda 1e-2
```
Epoch: (  0) (    1/   18) | Reg loss: 3.41490 |ncc loss: -0.05657 |  Smooth loss 3.47147
Epoch: (  0) (    2/   18) | Reg loss: 2.56414 |ncc loss: -0.05392 |  Smooth loss 2.61806

...
poch: ( 49) (    1/   18) | Reg loss: -0.06296 |ncc loss: -0.06447 |  Smooth loss 0.00151
Epoch: ( 49) (    2/   18) | Reg loss: -0.07609 |ncc loss: -0.07761 |  Smooth loss 0.00151

Epoch: ( 49) (    6/   18) | Reg loss: -0.04985 |ncc loss: -0.05129 |  Smooth loss 0.00144
```
The loss is too small because I think they count the background region aslo. My image size is 160x192x160.
This is attached file
[OASIS-TRT-20-12_moving.nii.gz](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/files/3552352/OASIS-TRT-20-12_moving.nii.gz)
[OASIS-TRT-20-12_fixed.nii.gz](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/files/3552353/OASIS-TRT-20-12_fixed.nii.gz)
[OASIS-TRT-20-12_reg.nii.gz](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/files/3552398/OASIS-TRT-20-12_reg.nii.gz)

In which, syn in ANTS still work well

![syn](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63883983-584ffc80-c9a3-11e9-98d4-56fed370ccc8.png)

Thanks in advance
with NCC, we recommend a lambda of around 1 or 1.5 (see main README or recommendation in the train.py arguments). Have you tried something in this range?

Yes. I tried lambda is 1 and it appears "noise" likes this one

![lambda](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63886651-fdb99f00-c9a8-11e9-9210-06a6a680450b.png)
[T1_OASIS-TRT-20-12_reg.nii.gz](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/files/3552547/T1_OASIS-TRT-20-12_reg.nii.gz)
[T1_OASIS-TRT-20-12_fixed.nii.gz](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/files/3552548/T1_OASIS-TRT-20-12_fixed.nii.gz)

oh interesting! never seen this before.
How do you compute the registered image?

How long did you train for? (although I don't believe this is an issue)

Also, can you show the flow field?

For lambda 1. This is the flow field. 
![step5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63888995-14162980-c9ae-11e9-83b8-6e4568f094e1.png)

Do you think my three steps are correct? The registered image computed by feed the two vals images (subject 12 (fixed) and subject 9(moving)) to the network to obtained deformation field. Then warp the subject 9 to warp images to obtain the moved image. Note that, the subject 12 and 9 do not appear in the training process. We use 1 to 8, 10, 11, 13 to 20 for training

I think the noise is the training is not long enough. I fixed it by training more epoch. However, the moved image still far away the fixed image

The steps look good conceptually. 

How long have you trained? Can you show the convergence curves? I have never seen that sort of weird artifact/block full deformation field.

The log is for ncc with your pretrained model and the result looks fine

So, I train it longer and it looks coverage. 
![step7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63897856-9b6e9780-c9c4-11e9-9e5e-bed8d8f23414.png)

I guess something happen in my pytorch code. Could you tell me when your group can public the pytorch code? It is very useful for me

Sorry, I don't have an estimate for the pytorch code, we'll announce when we're close.  I hadn't realized the issues above were with your own code.

For our code, how long did you let it run? THe results in the last screenshot certainly look better than what you have above -- so am i to understand that the last screenshot is from our provided code, and in the earlier message it's from your own pytorch code?

Right. Your code ran very fast. Just 20 mins to complete all and shown in the last screenshot. While my reporoduce is fist one. I found that the smooth loss may be wrong. In the beginning, my smooth loss is very high (~100), while your smooth loss is just 0.01. Do you have any trick for the smooth loss/flow loss?

This is my reproduce your smooth loss
```
    def smooothing_loss(self, y_pred):
        dy = torch.abs(y_pred[:, 1:, :, :] - y_pred[:, :-1, :, :])
        dx = torch.abs(y_pred[:, :, 1:, :] - y_pred[:, :, :-1, :])
        dz = torch.abs(y_pred[:, :, :, 1:] - y_pred[:, :, :, :-1])

        dx = torch.mul(dx, dx)
        dy = torch.mul(dy, dy)
        dz = torch.mul(dz, dz)
        d = torch.mean(dx) + torch.mean(dy) + torch.mean(dz)
        return d/3.0  
```

where y_pred is output of unet with size of `Bx3x160x192x224`, B is batch size. Do you think `y_pred[:, 1:, :, :] - y_pred[:, :-1, :, :]` should change to `y_pred[:, :, 1:, :, :] - y_pred[:, :, :-1, :, :]`

I am confused -- if your tensor is 5 dimension, why wouldn't you be indexing in five dimensions? Perhaps it's something I don't know about pytorch.

In your screenshots, you're not showing a colobar -- you really should, this would tell you, for example, the min and max of the resulting deformation field (the "bad" one from your pytorch), which would help you understand a bit of what's going on. The smoothing loss (as you call it) is really just a spatial derivative, so there's no magic/trick there.

@adalca : I would like to share your code result on OAIS dataset. From the result we can see that many wm and gm are merged together in the moved image. Do you suggest any reason? 

[Moving, Fixed | Moved Deformation Field]
![step9](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63944721-17f28c00-ca40-11e9-9d3c-1b4396f9bf77.png)

And it also appears some black line (top left) in the moving image. I am using NCC loss with lambda 1.0

![step3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63946330-f0e98980-ca42-11e9-9f5f-94c8890c046a.png)

Can you please add colorbars? It's informative for the deformation fields.

I'm not sure what you mean by mixing GM and WM, but I suspect that it's due to the smooth warp and interpolation. 

Do you find dramatically different effects with other algorithms?

Hi. Here is color bar

I used syn ants and its result is fine. Yes., mixing GM and WM means the GM in the moved image becomes WM (while ground-truth, it should be GM)

![sss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/63958647-bee32200-ca58-11e9-87ba-63c001d44234.png)

I'm sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Can you show me (perhaps use neuron.plot.slices in matlab):

12 | 13 | 12-moved-with-vm | 12-moved-with-ants

and then maybe highlight  (circle?) what you mean by the wm and gm mixing in voxelmorph and not in ants.
@John1231983 please see #109 for a discussion about a pytorch voxelmorph version.

@John1231983 hi, I saw you plot the result of [Moving, Fixed | Moved Deformation Field], however, I am wondering how you obtain the deformation filed? right now I can only get warp from register.py, or get flow filed from some specific layers. Thank you.
